title: Flashpoints: Uprising in Egypt
name: Flashpoints: Uprising in Egypt
description: Key locations in the anti-government protests.

properties.name: October 6 Bridge
properties.description: This bridge, a vital transportation link for Cairo residents, has been the scene of clashes between protesters and police.

properties.name: Tahrir Square
properties.description: Opposition figure and activist Mohamed ElBaradei speaks to the crowd at Tahrir Square on Jan. 30. (Reuters)Also known as Liberation Square, Tahrir Square in the centre of the city has been the focal point for demonstrations since Jan. 25, when a peaceful protest against the government of President Hosni Mubarak turned violent.Tens of thousands gathered in the square on Feb. 1 for a peaceful "march of a million people." CBC story

properties.name: National Democratic Party headquarters
properties.description: Protesters set fire to the Cairo headquarters of President Hosni Mubarak's party on the evening of Jan. 28.

properties.name: Nile River
properties.description: The river remains a focal point for Cairo, winding its way through the middle of the city.

properties.name: Interior Ministry building
properties.description: The ministry - home to the security apparatus that has helped to keep President Hosni Mubarak in power for three decades - is seen a powerful symbol of the regime's ruthlessness. Protesters gathered outside the building on Jan. 29 and reportedly tried to set it alight, but were turned back by the Egyptian military.

properties.name: Al-Azhar Mosque
properties.description: The mosque, a revered and historic institution for religious teaching, has become a gathering point for protesters, who clashed with police after Friday prayers on Jan. 28. Police fired rubber bullets at the demonstrators outside the prominent mosque, Reuters reported.More: Wall Street Journal blog

properties.name: Kasr al-Nile Bridge
properties.description: Protesters and riot police clashed on the bridge over the Nile River for hours on Jan. 28. Report: New York Times

properties.name: Egyptian Museum
properties.description: Looters broke into the famed museum of Egyptian antiquities on the night of Jan. 29, tearing the heads off two mummies and damaging about 10 objects before they were arrested.CBC story Video

properties.name: Cairo Airport
properties.description: Cairo's international gateway was filled on Jan. 30 with tourists and locals trying to flee the country. But a growing number of flights have been cancelled, delayed or suspended. The airport began to take on "the appearance of a marble-floored refugee camp," according to an Associated Press news report.

properties.name: The Great Pyramids
properties.description: The Egyptian military has closed tourist access to the world-famous attraction. Tanks and other armoured military vehicles have sealed off the site.

properties.name: Alexandria
properties.description: Thousands of protesters have been on the streets of Egypt's second-largest city. There have been reports of several fatalities.Police have fired tear gas and rubber bullets at the crowds, according to reports, and shops have been looted.Thousands of Muslim Brotherhood supporters attended a Jan. 30 funeral for one of their members that turned into an anti-government march, according to the Reuters news agency.Roads in and out of the city were closed on Feb. 1, the day of the "march of a million people."

properties.name: Ismaïlia
properties.description: Thousands of protesters have gathered in the city, the Reuters news agency reports. Police have used tear gas and rubber bullets, according to witness accounts.

properties.name: Damanhour
properties.description: Thousands took to the streets again on Jan. 31, according to the Reuters news agency.

properties.name: Suez
properties.description: The port city has seen some of the most violent protests since Jan. 25. More than a dozen people were killed in demonstrations Jan. 28 and Jan. 29 after the military was called in to attempt to restore order.Roads in and out of the city were closed on Feb. 1, the day of the "march of a million people."

properties.name: Mansoura
properties.description: Thousands protested here again on Jan. 31, according to a witness report given to the Reuters news agency.Roads in and out of the city were closed on Feb. 1, the day of the "march of a million people."

properties.name: Wadi Al Netroun
properties.description: Several thousand prisoners overwhelmed guards at the Wadi Natrun jail overnight on Jan. 29, the Agence France-Presse wire service reported. Those freed included leaders of the banned Muslim Brotherhood group. Eight people died in the riots, security sources told AFP.Australian Broadcasting Corporation story

properties.name: Tora prison
properties.description: Soldiers were stationed outside of Tora, one of Egypt's most notorious prisons, on Jan. 30 amid fears of another jailbreak.A wire service correspondent reported the sound of gunshots coming from within the complex, which was surrounded by troops with bayonets and an armoured personnel carrier.Australian Broadcasting Corporation story

properties.name: Suez Canal
properties.description: This vital shipping passage between the Red Sea and the Mediterranean has not been affected to date by the upheaval.
